page.title: 01HOWNAM IN ROXBURGHSHIRE
page.content: This tiny area of the Scottish Borders has the Kale Water running north in the centre, fed by 3 tributary burns, the Beirhope Burn from the west,the Capehope and Hownam burns from the east,giving a pattern of hills and vales,with the hamlet of Hownam beside the Kale, between the highest hills, Windy Law and Thowliestane Hill, both over 300 metres.Hownam consists of a Church, Hall, Post Office and only 9 houses,but is very much the hub of all the local inhabitants. The land is all used for farming, with almost equal areas of fenced hill and worked grass land, with very little cropping, only turnips and cabbage for animal winter feeding. Almost the entire permanant population is involved in farming, so most of the following pages are to do with life in a very rural community, it's farms, animals, and passtimes.
